column1: Sfântu Gheorghe (Romanian: [ˈsfɨntu ˈɡe̯orɡe]; Hungarian: Sepsiszentgyörgy or Szentgyörgy [ˈʃɛpʃisɛɲɟørɟ] (listen); Yiddish: סנט דזשארדזש‎) is the capital city of Covasna County
column2: Romania. Located in the central part of the country and in the historical region of Transylvania
column3: it lies on the Olt River in a valley between the Baraolt Mountains and Bodoc Mountains. The city administers two villages

column1: == Demographics ==

column1: == History ==
Sfântu Gheorghe is one of the oldest cities in Transylvania
column2: the settlement first having been documented in 1332. The city takes its name from Saint George
column3: the patron of the local church. Historically it was also known in German as Sankt Georgen. The "sepsi" prefix (sebesi → sepsi
column4: meaning "of Sebes") refers to the area which the ancestors of the local Székely population had inhabited before settling to the area of the town. The previous area of their settlement was around the town of "Sebes" (now: Sebeș) which later became populated mainly by Transylvanian Saxons.

column1: While part of the Kingdom of Hungary
column2: the city was the economic and administrative center of the Hungarian county of Háromszék
column3: which spanned the present-day Covasna County and parts of Brașov County. In the second half of the 19th century
column4: Sepsiszentgyörgy witnessed the development of light industry
column5: namely a textile and a cigarette factory was built. It became part of the Kingdom of Romania following the Treaty of Trianon in 1920
column6: after the end of World War I. After the Second Vienna Award in 1940 the city came under Hungarian control for four years. Near the end of that period
column7: the Sfântu Gheorghe ghetto briefly existed in the city. At the end of the Second World War the Paris Peace Treaties reaffirmed the city and the entirety of Transylvania as a Romanian territory. Between 1952 and 1960 it was the southernmost town of the Magyar Autonomous Region
column8: and between 1960 and 1968 was part of the Brașov Region
column9: abolished in 1968 when Romania was reorganised based on counties rather than regions.

column1: Sfântu Gheorghe is one of the centres for the Székely people in the region known to them as Székelyföld in Hungarian – which means "Székely Land"
column2: and is home to the Székely National Museum. The city hosts two market fairs each year.

== Economy ==

The predominant industry in the city is the textile industry. The city holds underutilized production capabilities such as a downsized automobile transmission parts and gearboxes factory (IMASA SA) and a tobacco factory (TIGARETE SA).Services sector contains growing areas such as IT services with ROMARG SRL the leading domain registrar and web hosting provider in Romania having its headquarters here.
== Sports ==
The main sport in the city is football. The city has a men's football team called ACS Sepsi OSK Sfântu Gheorghe (Sepsiszentgyörgyi OSK).
In the 2016–2017 season the team promoted from the 2nd Division and currently play in the Romanian 1st Division.
The city has also a women's basketball team called ACS Sepsi SIC. Sepsi-SIC has won the Romanian Championship in 2016

The Hungarian artist Jenő Gyárfás was born there and was a lifelong resident. His former studio is now an art gallery and exhibition hall.
